stem: Let \alpha, \beta, \gamma and \delta be the coefficients of x 7, x 5, x 3 and x respectively in the expansion of ( ) ( ) 5 5 3 3 x x 1 x x 1 + - + - - , x > 1. If u and v satisfy the equations \alphau + \betav = 18, \gammau + \deltav = 20, then u + v equals : (1) 5 (2) 4 (3) 3 (4) 8
subject: Algebra

stem: In a group of 3 girls and 4 boys, there are two boys B1 and B2. The number of ways, in which these girls and boys can stand in a queue such that all the girls stand together, all the boys stand together, but B1 and B2 are not adjacent to each other, is : (1) 144 (2) 72 (3) 96 (4) 120

options.text: Sol. Total – when B1 and B2 are together

explanation: Total – when B1 and B2 are together = 2!(3! 4!) – 2! (3!(3! 2!)) = 144
subject: Algebra

stem: For a 3 × 3 matrix M, let trace (M) denote the sum of all the diagonal elements of M. Let A be a 3 × 3 matrix such that |A| = 1 2 and trace (A) = 3. If B = adj(adj(2A)), then the value of |B| + trace (B) equals: (1) 56 (2) 132 (3) 174 (4) 280
subject: Algebra

stem: Suppose that the number of terms in an A.P. is 2k, kN. If the sum of all odd terms of the A.P. is 40, the sum of all even terms is 55 and the last term of the A.P. exceeds the first term by 27, then k is equal to (1) 5 (2) 8 (3) 6 (4) 4

stem: The sum of all values of \theta  [0, 2\pi] satisfying 2sin 2\theta = cos2\theta and 2cos 2\theta = 3sin\theta is (1) 2 \pi (2) 4\pi (3) 5 6 \pi (4) \pi
explanation: 2sin 2\theta = cos2\theta  2sin 2\theta = 1 – 2sin 2\theta  4sin 2\theta = 1  sin 2\theta = 1 4 ALLEN 6   sin\theta = ± 1 2  2cos 2\theta = 3sin\theta 2 – 2sin 2\theta + 3sin\theta– 2 = 0 (2sin\theta – 1)(2sin\theta – 2) = 0 sin\theta = 1 2 so common equation which satisfy both equations is sin\theta = 1 2 5 , 6 6 \pi \pi \theta = (\theta[0, 2\pi]) Sum = \pi

stem: Let A(6, 8), B(10 cos\alpha, –10 sin\alpha) and C (–10 sin\alpha, 10 cos\alpha), be the vertices of a triangle. If L(a, 9) and G(h, k) be its orthocenter and centroid respectively, then (5a – 3h + 6k + 100 sin2\alpha) is equal to___________

options.text: Sol. All the three points A, B, C lie on the circle

explanation: All the three points A, B, C lie on the circle x 2 + y 2 = 100 so circumcentre is (0, 0) 1 L(a,9) 2 O(0,0) G(h,k) a 0 h 3 + =  a = 3h and 9 0 k 3 + =  k = 3 also centroid 6 10cos 10sin h 3 + \alpha - \alpha =  10(cos\alpha – sin\alpha) = 3h – 6 ….(i) and 8 10cos 10sin k 3 + \alpha - \alpha =  10(cos\alpha – sin\alpha) = 3k – 8 = 9 – 8 = 1 ….(ii) on squaring 100(1 – sin2\alpha) = 1  100sin2\alpha = 99 from equ. (i) and (ii) we get h = 7 3 Now 5a – 3h + 6k + 100 sin2\alpha = 15h – 3h + 6k + 100 sin2\alpha = 12 × 7 3 + 18 + 99 = 145
subject: Mathematics

stem: Let the distance between two parallel lines be 5 units and a point P lie between the lines at a unit distance from one of them. An equilateral triangle PQR is formed such that Q lies on one of the parallel lines, while R lies on the other. Then (QR) 2 is equal to ________.
explanation: P 60° Q R 60° 90°–\theta \theta 30°+\theta d PR = cosec\theta, PQ = 4sec(30 + \theta) For equilateral d = PR = PQ  cos(\theta + 30°) = 4sin\theta  3 1 cos sin 4sin 2 2 \theta- \theta = \theta  1 tan 3 3 \theta = QR 2 = d 2 = cosec 2\theta = 28
subject: Coordinate Geometry

stem: Let A = {1, 2, 3}. The number of relations on A, containing (1, 2) and (2, 3), which are reflexive and transitive but not symmetric, is ______.
explanation: Transitivity (1, 2)  R, (2, 3)  R  (1, 3)  R For reflexive (1, 1), (2, 2) (3, 3)  R Now (2, 1), (3, 2), (3, 1) (3, 1) cannot be taken (1) (2, 1) taken and (3, 2) not taken (2) (3, 2) taken and (2, 1) not taken (3) Both not taken therefore 3 relations are possible. ALLEN
subject: Algebra
